;在四川省省会成都的西南科技中心，Matthew Chen 与成立了一家小型视频游戏工作室和发行商，该公司最近采用生成式人工智能 (AI) 技术来提高效率，同时大大减少人力需求——这是世界第二大经济体的新兴趋势。

;

;作者采用两种外国开发的工具——Stable Diffusion，一种基于文本描述生成详细图像的深度学习系统，以及人工智能聊天机器人 ChatGPT——这两种工具在中国均未正式上市，陈的公司今年已经摆脱了一大群承包商

;

;“ChatGPT 的翻译速度要快得多，每月只需 20 美元，”陈说。他说，相比之下，第三方翻译公司一年的合同收费高达 10 万元人民币（14,000 美元）。

;

;撰稿人、外语客服人员和一些插画师也可以更换据陈说，由人工智能。他说他的公司正在试验 Stable Diffusion，将文字提示变成图像，将粗略的草图变成图像。他说，这个系统的表现大约是人类插画师的 80%。

;

;在生成式 AI 技术对某些传统职业带来的全面颠覆中，陈的视频游戏工作室所做的改变只是其中的一小部分

;

;在 3 月下旬发布的全球分析中，高盛估计生成式 AI 可以使多达 3 亿个全职工作岗位实现自动化。

;

;这家美国投资银行发现，在美国和欧洲，四分之一的当前任务可以通过人工智能实现自动化，列出了办公室行政支持、法律、建筑和工程等部门。

;

;在中国，风险似乎更高，低出生率与人口迅速老龄化相结合，导致人口失衡加剧。中国创历史新高的青年失业率也使这种情况变得复杂。

;

;AI 可能会使中国一半的工作面临风险。我们向 ChatGPT 寻求职业建议

;

;今年夏天有 1160 万新大学毕业生，比去年增加了约 82 万，他们将进入中国的就业市场，而中国的就业市场已经充斥着在冠状病毒期间大学毕业但未成功的求职者

;

;北京大学国家发展学院副教授张丹丹最近对中国招聘网站上的 120 万个职位进行的一项研究发现，对于那些很容易找到的职位，就业机会正在迅速消失根据上海数字媒体界面界面的一份报告，人工智能正在取代人工智能，包括销售、会计、培训、软件开发、办公室管理和客户服务。

;

;研究表明，人工智能正在带走更多界面新闻援引张的话说，中国的传统职业比创造新的就业机会还多，这种趋势可能会加剧。上个月，她在首都举行的一次学术研讨会上分享了她的研究成果。

;

;虽然中国政府尚未对该国就业市场中与 AI 相关的总体破坏做出估计，但该技术的影响正在变得越来越大更明显。受官方控制的《每日经济新闻》最近的一篇报道称，受灾最严重的行业之一是留学中介，中介机构为留学申请准备相关文书工作，该报道称 ChatGPT 正在扼杀这一行业。

;< h3>;ChatGPT 老板称 AI 不会引发大规模工作岗位灭绝;

;报道援引一家帮助中国学生出国留学的公司经营者张烨的话说，他的公司已经失去了 60 多个其 % 的业务是通过 ChatGPT 将应用程序“抛光”为“高质量”工作。

;

;使用大型语言模型 (LLM)，如美国初创公司 OpenAI 开发的最新版本 GPT-4根据中国电子商务巨头阿里巴巴集团控股的内部研究机构达摩院最近的一项研究，其 ChatGPT 服务的成本也不到聘请人类数据分析师的 1%，同时获得了可比的表现。新加坡南洋理工大学。阿里巴巴拥有南华早报。

;

;LLM 是一种深度学习算法，可以根据从海量数据集中获得的知识来识别、总结、翻译、预测和生成文本和其他内容。

;

;目前，中国政府尚未正式批准任何国内 ChatGPT 式服务。百度的Ernie Bot、商汤科技的SenseChat、科大讯飞的SparkDesk和阿里巴巴的统一千文都被认为处于“试用模式”。与此同时，ChatGPT 和谷歌的 Bard 在拥有世界上最多互联网人口的中国无法直接使用。

;

;AI 行业是中国毕业生艰难就业市场中的一个亮点

;

;仍然，精通技术的中国用户在各种本地工作中使用了 ChatGPT。

;

;一位姓张的社会科学研究人员和大学教授在他对编程语言 R 的数据分析中形容 ChatGPT “非常可靠”用于统计计算和图形，以及通用 Python 编程语言。

;

;“我过去常常将 20% 到 30% 的时间花在作业上”，例如编写课程大纲、为教职员工起草演讲稿并编写会议议程，张说。 “ChatGPT 非常擅长生成不需要包含论据或原创性的内容，但它不会变成一篇前卫的学术论文。”

;

;也有一些企业和行业已经广泛采用这些新的 AI 工具并创造了新的就业机会。

;

;文案、设计师、插画师和翻译人员也可以使用生成式 AI 来改进他们的工作，而且不一定会被取代，中心主任 Pascale Fung 表示香港科技大学人工智能研究中心。

;

;“可能创造的工作是那些使用人工智能来提高效率和创造力的工作，”冯说。 “将会有新一代的 AI 设计师、内容创作者、分析师、架构师、艺术家等，他们知道如何利用生成式 AI 的力量。”

;

;关于 Boss 直聘，一个针对目标人群的中国招聘平台科技工作者，本周至少列出了 27 个“快速工程师”的职位空缺，这是一个相对较新的职位，可以优化与生成 AI 的交互。

;

;雇主包括一些中国最大的互联网公司，包括 TikTok 所有者 ByteDance，语音识别巨头 iFlytek 和 Jidu，这是一家由百度和汽车制造商吉利支持的电动汽车企业。据负责技术的公司代表在给邮报的书面回复中称，总部位于杭州的智能营销机构 Mogic 也在寻找大约五名提示工程师，这是 5 月份新设的职位。

;

;提示工程师应具备理解LLM、编写代码、分析数据和了解营销的综合能力。 “例如，提示工程师必须了解短视频的工作原理，才能要求生成式 AI 提供正确的脚本，”Mogic 代表说。

;

;即使是中国的应届毕业生，那些拥有法学硕士相关学位的人求职平台猎聘发布的 2023 年中国大学毕业生就业报告显示，职位空缺数量同比激增 172.5%。

;香港计划输入工人将让航空公司增加航班数量并帮助该市机场负责人表示，航空业将在冬季旺季之前将机票价格降至“合理水平”。

;

;当地地勤人员短缺导致 20 家航空公司难以增加航班数量过去三个月，机管局行政总裁林天福周日亦透露。

;

;“我们希望到年底，航班及旅客数量能恢复至疫情前的80%今年 [有了新措施]，”他说。

;

;上周，香港公布了进口多达 20,000 名工人以支持建筑、运输和航空部门的计划，这将绕过政府的审查程序劳工顾问委员会。

;

;输入 20,000 名工人能否解决香港的劳工问题？

;

;作为该计划的一部分，航空业获准输入 6,300 名工人。

;< p>;Lam 表示，机场的人力短缺，包括地勤人员、司机、机组人员和维修人员的短缺，阻碍了航空公司提高航班运力，并阻碍了该行业的复苏。

;

;他预计第一个一批进口工人将于 10 月抵达并在 12 月完成培训，正好赶上圣诞节前后的旅游旺季。

;

;“航空公司急于增加航班数量以满足圣诞节期间的需求， “ 他说。 “我们希望外劳可以帮助我们增加航班，将机票价格拉低到一个相对合理的水平。”

;

;早前有旅行社表示，香港的机票价格上涨了15至40元不等。与大流行前的价格相比，下降了 %。

;

;香港的旗舰航空公司国泰航空此前预测，机票价格将在明年年底前保持高位，并指出机票供不应求。

;

;香港的旗舰航空公司及其廉价子公司香港快运航空在 3 月份的载客量达到了大流行前的 50%，而区域竞争对手新加坡航空集团为 79%。

;

;周日， Lam 还对输入劳动力会对本地工人产生负面影响的担忧置之不理，认为他们可以承担监督新移民的任务。

;

;强调采用技术和自动化以尽量减少对人力的需求的重要性，他承诺通过香港国际航空学院吸引年轻的本地人才加入该行业。

;

;输入劳工不足以解决香港面临的更广泛问题

;

;尽管香港积极推动为了引进更多劳动力，香港民航职工会早些时候预测，机场运营商将难以通过目前的薪酬方案从附近的中国内地城市争取到工人。

;

;援引与总部位于深圳的会谈机场工作人员，它认为大陆人更愿意在国内从事类似薪酬的工作，而无需搬迁或每天长时间通勤的麻烦。

;

;副财政司司长黄伟伦承认该计划将不得不应对通勤“挑战”和来自其他城市的竞争，但认为香港的薪酬仍高于跨境。

;每周三次，一次20元（2.8美元），北京-银行家 Fred Jia 下班后买彩票成了家常便饭。

;

;他是因为去年的世界杯足球赛养成了这个习惯，在卡塔尔世界杯结束后又开始买其他类型的彩票。

;

;每次，这位 28 岁的年轻人都挤过人群——其中许多是中年男子，手里拿着香烟，阅读点缀着过去中奖号码的图表并分享经验——在小彩票中

;

;

;“我想变得富有并改变我的生活，但我的工作不能给我带来这些，”他说。 “你怎么知道你不会成为下一个大赢家？”;

;在冠状病毒后经济复苏乏力和就业市场恶化的情况下，更多像贾一样的中国年轻人在购买彩票中找到了慰藉，

;

;

;除中国体育彩票和中国福利彩票外，中国普遍禁止赌博，这两种彩票都有涉及选号的传统彩票和提供即时中奖潜力的刮刮卡。< /p>;

;体育彩票涉及游戏元素，因为客户可以预测足球比赛的结果并根据结果进行投注。与此同时，中国福利彩票通过销售彩票来助力社会公益事业的发展。

;

;社交媒体上的帖子也充斥着中国的各个平台，“中千万比赚容易”的口号1000 万”成为许多人新的人生格言。

;

;去年，Wayne Zheng 被中国热门视频共享服务哔哩哔哩上的视频拖到购买刮刮卡。

;

;27 年-old看着别人大量买卡，每次赢了，不管赢多少，他都为他们感到高兴。

;

;然后郑开始给自己买刮刮卡，每当他路过一家店时，他会花50元到200元。如果他在特定的商店赢了，他会确保他回来。

;

;“那是在 Covid-19 大流行期间，当时我感到生活非常困难和压力很大，”这位上海居民说。

;

; p>;

;“我开始买[刮刮卡]，因为我真的很想一夜暴富。”

;

;根据财政部的数据，创纪录的 1751.5 亿元人民币（245 亿美元）的今年前四个月，全国彩票和刮刮卡销量同比增长 49.3%。

;

;中国 31 个省级辖区均出现销量激增数据显示，同一时期。

;

;该部门将销量激增归因于足球世界杯等热门体育赛事，以及新彩票游戏（主要是刮刮卡）的推广。

;

;但经济学家表示，经济前景黯淡以及政府财政状况恶化是更深层次的原因。

;

;恒生银行中国首席经济学家王丹表示，北京通常不鼓励买彩票彩票和刮刮卡，因为它本质上是一种赌博形式，但如此高的收入反映了通过更传统的方式筹集资金的困难。

;

;2021 年，在价值 3733 亿元的彩票和刮刮卡中根据财政部的数据，在全国范围内销售的信用卡中，28%（即 1047 亿元人民币）最终成为政府收入，中央和地方政府进一步平均分配，并指定用于公益支出。

;

;上周，该部批准了 20 种以体育为主题的新型刮刮卡。

;

;“彩票本质上是对穷人征税，”王说。

;

;“就业市场尤其在经济不景气时对低收入群体很苛刻。许多人转向彩票作为一种逃避。”

;一架英国航空公司的航班在 30,000 米时遇到严重的湍流，被迫折返脚，留下一名机组人员需要手术。

;

;《太阳报》率先报道称，周五从新加坡樟宜飞往伦敦希思罗机场的英航 12 号航班在孟加拉湾上空遇到严重湍流，造成 5 名空乘人员受伤。

;

;一位消息人士告诉《太阳报》，飞机遭遇的湍流是“令人讨厌的”。

;

;“不知从哪里开始，飞机开始摇晃，它突然下降了 5 英尺，然后又以令人不舒服的猛拉动作再次升起。乘客们发出尖叫声，机舱内弥漫着巨大的不安情绪，”该人士告诉媒体。

;全球钢铁行业可在 2040 年代初实现净零排放，早于2050 年全球目标，但这将需要政府和行业“迅速采取行动”，包括建立监管框架和扩大新技术以降低成本，一项研究表明。

;

;这是可行的德国非营利性气候智库 Agora Industry 和伍珀塔尔气候、环境与能源研究所周四在一份联合报告中表示，到 2043 年至 2045 年逐步淘汰炼钢用煤，而不会“过早关闭”钢厂，这注入了乐观情绪关于对难以减排的碳密集型行业进行脱碳。

;

;“我们的研究表明，是时候从钢铁行业中去除‘难以减排’的标签了，”Frank Peter，董事Agora Industry 在一份声明中说。 “实现净零排放所需的技术和战略已经存在——现在政府和公司需要联合起来快速部署它们。”

;

;更高的材料利用效率，使用回收废料炼钢的显着增加和报告称，氢基钢铁生产的商业化是实现这一目标的关键。

;

;到 2021 年，钢铁行业的碳排放量约为 27.5 亿吨，占全球排放量的 7.5%，预计将下降根据国际能源署去年 10 月发布的一份报告，根据钢铁制造商宣布的承诺，到 2040 年将减少到 18 亿吨，到 2050 年将减少到 11.2 亿吨。

;

;到目前为止，全球钢铁企业的一半工业产能已承诺到 2050 年实现净零排放，科学家们表示，到 2100 年全球变暖需要控制在 1.5 摄氏度，以避免气候变化造成灾难性的经济和社会后果。

;

;没有“银弹”绿色钢铁生产需要多种解决方案：报告

;

;总部位于瑞士的世界可持续发展工商理事会首席执行官彼得·巴克表示，在中国制造的全球汽车制造商将成为绿色钢铁需求的主要推动力梅赛德斯-奔驰集团诚信与企业责任顾问委员会成员。

;

;中国是全球最大的汽车市场，去年钢铁产量占全球的 53.7%。

;

;2019 年，这家德国公司公布了到 2039 年使其整个新车队在整个价值链和生命周期中实现碳中和的雄心。

;

;“许多全球汽车品牌都在中国设立了合资企业，”Bakker 说. “他们将向中国供应商施加压力，要求他们生产绿色钢铁。与此同时，比亚迪和蔚来等公司将需要使用绿色钢铁制造出口到发达市场的零排放汽车，否则人们不会购买。”

;

;Bakker 预计国际标准将在一个周期内出现计算消费品整个供应链碳排放量的方法，这将有助于在可持续性方面区分竞争对手的产品。

;

;在炼钢中使用氢气是实现近零排放的关键技术途径报告称，从长远来看，这对工业来说是一个长期的行业。

;

;但据 Agora Industry 称，目前全球工程和建设能力仅足以每年使用低碳氢生产 7000 万吨钢铁。这相当于该行业到 2030 年实现 1.5 度全球变暖目标所需的额外产能的一半左右。

;

;“一个关键的解决方案是对工程师和建筑工人进行再培训以制造直接还原铁植物，”Agora 的报告称。 “另一个解决方案是促进新参与者的进入。”

;

;低碳氢的成本将成为决定钢厂未来竞争力的关键因素，钢厂会发现进口低碳氢在经济上更具吸引力-碳铁，它说，而不是长距离运输氢气并用它来生产低碳钢。低碳铁是指使用能源密集度较低且排放量较少的方法生产的金属。

;

;与此同时，澳大利亚铁矿巨头必和必拓周五在博客中表示，它计划帮助炼钢行业开发能够到 2030 年将排放量减少 30% 的技术，并补充说该行业必须寻求多种途径来实现脱碳。

;

;由于中国用于节能炼钢的废钢供应有限必和必拓表示，必须为在高炉中将铁矿石和煤炼钢的工厂开发减排技术。使用高炉的碳密集型生产占全球钢铁产能的 70%，在中国占 90%。

;

;此类减排技术包括注氢、气体回收、碳捕获和用生物质替代品替代化石燃料，必和必拓的可持续发展高管在博客中表示。

;

;“要在 2030 年代大幅降低初级钢铁生产的排放强度......需要与其他工艺路线同时采用高炉改造技术来减少排放，我们认为这可能需要更长的时间，”他们说。

; Sun, 18 Jun 2023 10:20:02 +0800 Why are mainland Chinese professionals dominating Hong Kong’s global hunt for talent?https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/3224419/why-are-mainland-chinese-professionals-dominating-hong-kongs-global-hunt-talent?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.18 09:00;
;;

;当猎头 Briant Neo Wen-xi 寻找时，中国大陆的求职者感受到了他们的存在为他的香港客户填补职位空缺。

;

;从 3 月到本月，Neo 帮助安置了 20 名合格的大陆员工，这是他在过去五年中招聘的大陆员工人数最多的一次。

;

;他们从事技术、医疗保健、生命科学、银行、金融服务和保险等领域的工作。

;

;Kairos 的首席执行官 Neo 在招聘行业拥有超过 12 年的经验Global Search 表示，与 Covid-19 大流行之前相比，为他的香港客户雇用的大陆人数量显着增加。

;

;95% 的香港人才计划获批申请人来自中国大陆

;

;他估计，在 2016 年至 2019 年间，他每年招聘的人才中，只有约五分之一来自大陆。自 2020 年以来，他们的比例已增至约一半，他预计这一趋势将持续下去。

;

;“越来越多的香港公司认识到需要利用内地求职者的技能和知识，以在不断变化的环境中保持竞争力商业格局，”他说。

;

;随着香港从三年的 Covid-19 和世界上一些最严厉的流行病限制中走出来，遭受重创的经济需要注入全球人才来帮助它反弹作为国际金融中心。

;

;然而，到目前为止，内地工人的数量超过了来自世界其他地区的工人，他们来到这座城市从事关键行业的工作，包括金融服务、工程和建筑以及高等教育。

;

;该市有七个重点人才计划，大陆人有资格获得五个。根据移民局的数据，越来越多的内地人通过这些计划申请来港工作并获准来港工作。

;

;在过去 11 个月的时间里，各种人才计划下总共有 51,032 人获得批准今年2月，三分之二的成功申请者来自大陆。

;

;他们共获批33,976份工作签证，其中17,056份签发给非大陆人，包括来自英国、澳大利亚、日本、韩国、美国、印度和法国。

;

;香港行政长官李家超去年 10 月透露，过去两年约有 14 万人离开香港后，香港当局推出了几项旨在吸引各地人士的措施

;

;根据 Top Talent Pass Scheme，成功的候选人将获得为期两年的签证。符合条件的工人包括过去12个月收入不少于250万港元（319美元、113美元）的人，以及过去五年中工作满三年的世界百强大学毕业生，两组均不限。< /p>;

;世界前100名大学近5年毕业生，工作经验3年以下也可申请，但每年名额上限为10000人。

;

;必须全力以赴in Hong Kong's hunt for top academic talent

;

;As of February, 8,325 workers out of 8,797 approved under this new scheme came from the mainland, with only several dozens from other countries such as the US, Canada, Australia and Singapore.

;

;The trend is a sharp contrast with the situation in the 2018-19 financial year ending March 31, before the city was hit by months of social unrest and the pandemic.

;

; Over that period, the 24,128 mainlanders recently approved under talent schemes were outnumbered by 42,868 from other countries.

;

;Some foreign business chambers have warned that Hong Kong needs to draw upon a diverse pool of talent instead of overly relying on mainland workers, but others who spoke to the Post have said the trend does not worry them.

;

;Basil Hwang, vice-chairman of the Singapore Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong, said overseas talent was a “fundamental” aspect of Hong Kong as an international city and these individuals provided a way for the city to hedge against geopolitical risks as it created value for the rest of the world.

;

;The recent trend of mainlanders outnumbering talent from elsewhere was of concern, he said, as it raised questions of whether the city was simply attracting a small number of global applicants or if there was a disproportionate preference for approving mainland applicants.

;

;David Graham, executive director of the British Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong, said it was not surprising that more mainlanders applied to come to the city between last year and February this year, when Hong Kong lifted its pandemic restrictions.

;

;He said there was a negative sentiment overseas about Hong Kong, one of the last places globally to reopen.

;

;“But we may see a change in the applications as we move through 2023 and into 2024, and have more international visits from senior business leaders ,” he said.

;

;He added that as a connector between East and West, Hong Kong needed to bring in international talent alongside local and mainland workers.

;

;“This blend of talent has been a distinguishing feature of Hong Kong and one of its attractions,” he said.

;

;3 in 4 Hong Kong companies struggling with talent shortage, chamber survey finds

;

;Graham said he believed the city remained attractive to British talent, with its infrastructure, low tax regime, regulatory framework, cultural scene and easy access to nature.

;

;Revealing that the chamber had begun seeing more interest and enquiries from British companies hoping to come to the city, he said: “Anecdotally, we are seeing some talent coming back to Hong Kong from among our members, but we expect to have a clearer idea at the end of the year or into 2024.”

;

;George Leung Siu-kay, CEO of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce, said the sharp increase in mainland talent heading to the city reflected rising education levels there.

;

;“Hong Kong still has a good diversity of talented professionals from around the world, and this mix is largely determined by supply and demand of market forces,” he said.

;

;But he added that as an international business hub, the city needed well-qualified people from around the world to work for companies targeting different markets and provide expertise and experience unavailable locally.

;

;39 overseas academics recruited to Hong Kong; some say labs, home costs a deterrent

;

;Some foreigners start arriving

;

;Among those unsurprised by the trend of mainlanders arriving in Hong Kong was Armstrong Lee Hon-cheung, managing director of executive search firm Worldwide Consulting Group.

;

;“Firstly, Hong Kong has a similar culture to the mainland,” he said. “Secondly, the mainland is very close to Hong Kong, making it easy for mainlanders to acclimatise to Hong Kong.”

;

;Besides, he added, Hong Kong's development was closely aligned to that of the mainland and as more Chinese companies moved to the city, they hired mainlanders with experience.

;

;He thought that a mix of housing perks and tax rebates would bring back global talent to Hong Kong, but added that ultimately, employers played a part in deciding whether these individuals remained in the city.

;

;“When you are employed in a job, if you do it well, have good promotion prospects and your salary is good, you will stay even if the environment in Hong Kong does not change,” he said. “This is because you already came to the city and have got used to its policies, life and infrastructure.”

;

;As Hong Kong looks overseas, local talent needs to be nurtured

;

;Lingnan University human resources scholar Frankie Lam King-sun agreed that Hong Kong's status as an international financial centre would continue to draw talent.

;

;Both said the city's tough pandemic social-distancing and travel restrictions were the main reason foreigners left over the past three years.

;

;To bring them back, Lam said the authorities had to work harder to push the message that Hong Kong had returned to normality after the pandemic, and provide them tax breaks or education subsidies for their children.

;

;Lee Quane, regional director for Asia at management consultancy firm ECA International, pointed out that the pandemic had hurt the economy so badly that there were fewer jobs currently for international talent.

;

;Changes in the city's political environment in recent years would also have put off overseas talent who cared about freedom of speech and democracy, he said.

;

;In the wake of months of anti-government protests in 2019, Beijing imposed the national security law in 2020, banning acts of secession, subversion, terrorism and collusion with foreign forces. That was followed by an overhaul of the electoral system to ensure that only “patriots” run the city.

;

;Accompanying the changes were the closure of several independent media outlets, the disbandment of civil society groups, and the arrests of many political activists.

;

;“As Hong Kong changes and moves away from what it was like five years ago towards a more politically restrained environment, that's also going to deter international talent from staying in Hong Kong,” Quane said, adding that negative perceptions of the city's political changes had to be addressed.

;

;To attract global talent, he suggested promoting the city's advantages compared with other locations, such as the relative ease for dependants of expatriates to find work, and addressing the high cost of living.

;

;Lawmaker Johnny Ng Kit-chong, an entrepreneur who has incubated biotech and fintech start-ups, conceded that some foreign talent had been concerned about the political environment, but believed they were a minority and most were unhappy about the pandemic restrictions.

;

;“When it comes to the political situation, we should just give everyone time to see the situation for themselves,” he said. “We need to prove that after the reform of the election system, the government's efficiency has really increased, the things that it has done have actually improved the lives of residents.”

;

;'Challenged books' swept off Hong Kong library shelves, but what about shops?

;

;While the number of foreigners has yet to rebound to pre-pandemic levels, Hong Kong has seen some arriving in recent years.

;

;In the 2020-21 financial year, the latest with complete data, financial services, commerce and trade, academic research and education were the top three industries with approved applicants under the General Employment Policy – the main scheme admitting overseas talent. All saw more than 2,000 approvals.

;

;Of the 13,526 foreigners who arrived under the scheme, 5,261 had jobs paying between HK$20,000 and HK$39,999 a month, 4,065 earned between HK$40,000 and HK$79,999, while 2,691 earned HK$80,000 or more, according to the immigration department data.

;

;Among those who decided to take a chance on Hong Kong was Felicia Teh, 45, a senior human resources professional at a multinational company.

;

;She moved from Malaysia to Hong Kong last September to take a job she described as a step up in her career that came with a promotion and pay rise.

;

;“I've been here nine months and I would confidently and without reservation say that Hong Kong offers unparalleled experiences both in the social and professional setting … this is a rare find globally,” she said. “I'm so delighted to be able to experience nature, culture and so many dining options.”

;

;Hong Kong loses spot 'as most enticing city in China' for East Asian expats

;

;Teh, whose husband was also in Hong Kong, said they planned to stay for “the mid-to long-term” and was optimistic the city would bounce back.

;

;“I think Hong Kong will continue to attract new international talent to its shores. Many have left, but many new ones, perhaps better ones, will come,” she said.

;

;When Hong Kong software start-up SeekFlow began recruiting online and took part in career events at universities in the city this year, it noticed more interest from mainland talent.

;

;The six mainlanders hired for its local research and development team now make up almost a tenth of the Hong Kong office's team of more than 70.

;

;“When we do career talks or join career fairs at the city's eight publicly funded universities, we've also met quite a number of mainland candidates,” said the company's chief of staff, Xenia Chu.

;

;“Having fewer people to select from is something we really worry about. Having more, no matter what their nationality, is a good thing.”

;A 60-year-old woman from China has become the envy of many online thanks to a physique she has built through disciplined fitness training.

;

;Bao Xiaoling, 60, from Jiangsu province in the east of the country, is a pensioner as well as a part-time cardio trainer at five gyms, the Jiangsu Broadcasting Corporation reported on June 12.

;

;She has been obsessed with fitness training since the age of 38 when she attended an aerobics course to lose weight after finding she could no longer fit into her clothes.

;

;It was a time when fitness culture had just emerged in China and most gyms only offered simple workouts like aerobics.

;

;After attending the fitness class for six months, Bao said other members told her that her movements were of a higher standard than those of their coach.

;

;Encouraged by the flattery, she signed up for the aerobics instructor certification exam. She said only six or seven people from her province sat the exam, which she passed.

;

;In another interview with Qianjiang Evening News, the gym lover said her daily routine included waking up at 7.30am and working out before breakfast.

;

;Every day between 3pm and 4pm is her time to pump iron.

;

;“My waist size was 27 inches (68.6cm) when I was 20, and now it is 25 inches (63.5cm),” she said.

;

;Bao said she had a group of fans in their 20s who followed her lifestyle and training routines.

;

;“Fitness has become a part of my life,” Bao said. “My biggest lessons from my 20-years of fitness training is that exercise brings confidence, health and a young mentality.”

;

;She said keeping fit did not have an age limit, and did not necessarily have to take place in gyms.

;

;On Chinese social media, many said they were inspired by her optimistic outlook.

;

;“I hope I can be like her when I am 60,” one woman said.

;

;“She is not an auntie, but a sister,” said another, referring to Bao's age-defying appearance.

;

;“Exercise makes a person young, both physically and mentally,” a third commented.

;

;Previously, Bao was a member of a group of women who kept daily fitness routines in their 50s. All looking much younger than their years, the group of eight named themselves the “ageless grannies”.

;

;An age-defying man, 73-year-old Hu Hai, dubbed Shanghai's “most modern grandpa”, also made headlines earlier this year.

;

;Hu said he looked so fit and young that many people were confused when they saw him, not knowing if they should address him as brother, uncle or grandpa.

;

;He said his secret to staying young was eating frugally and regular exercise.

; Sun, 18 Jun 2023 09:20:02 +0800 How Saudi Arabia is teeing up for global golf and disrupting the West’s dominancehttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/opinion/article/3224382/how-saudi-arabia-teeing-global-golf-and-disrupting-wests-dominance?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.18 08:30;
;;

;Professional golf – and increasingly world sport – is caught in a sand trap. Not the familiar hazard between fairway and green, but the Middle Eastern desert producing enormous quantities of fossil fuels.

;

;The resulting riches are being diverted into sport, disrupting its traditional Western dominance.

;

;The latest example is the dramatic announcement that LIV Golf, the rebel circuit led by retired Australian golfer Greg Norman and backed by Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, is merging with the US PGA and European DP World Tours after two years of trench warfare.

;

;While today's big story is LIV Golf, Saudi Arabia's involvement in sport will generate many more money-driven, politics-heavy headlines.

;

;

;

;There are echoes here of Kerry Packer's World Series Cricket and Rupert Murdoch's Super (Rugby) League. An aggressive, well-funded competitor takes on the sport establishment, promising to shake up a rigid game, and bringing in new money and younger fans with lashings of razzmatazz.

;

;LIV Golf offers shorter-stroke play contests and a competitive team format. In April, Australia got a taste of it in Adelaide. Large, raucous crowds turned up, witnessing innovations like a “party hole” complete with terrace, bars and a DJ.

;

;LIV lured leading golfers such as Australia's Cameron Smith with enormous contracts, in his case worth A$140 million (US$95.7 million). In response, the main tours banned LIV-signed golfers from most of their tournaments.

;

;Inevitably, it ended up in the courts, with LIV suing the PGA Tour for what it said were restrictive practices, and the PGA countersuing for inducement to break contracts.

;

;Peace suddenly broke out last week via a joint press release announcing that the tours and LIV Golf would morph into a collectively owned, for-profit entity. This came as a shock to tour golfers in an ostensibly player-run organisation, who found out via Twitter.

;

;Even Greg Norman – a pivotal but deeply divisive figure – was apparently blindsided by the move and discarded.

;

;With Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund governor Yasir Al-Rumayyan as chair and PGA Tour commissioner Jay Monahan as chief executive, the so-far unnamed entity must heal some deep wounds. Golfers who refused massive LIV contracts and believed Monahan's defiant rhetoric feel sold down the river. It will take more than boosterish words from golf's inner circle to placate them.

;

;Golf's turmoil is symptomatic of the impact of huge injections of capital into sport from outside the US and Europe. It does not only come from the Middle East. The Indian Premier League, both men's and women's, has comprehensively refashioned the economy of world cricket.

;

;China has invested huge sums in football, and Beijing is the only city to have hosted both the Summer and Winter Olympics.

;

;But the Middle East is where commercial sport is seen as the future of a post-carbon economy. Last year, Qatar hosted the men's Fifa World Cup and is steadily supplementing its sports infrastructure, while the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain have committed large sums to motorsports and cricket.

;

;Saudi Arabia is making the biggest impact on global sport through its US$1.1 trillion Vision 2030 plan to diversify its economy under leader Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, also known as MBS.

;

;

;

;Human rights come to the fore every time such non-Western countries host a major sports tournament or buy a major sports property. A 2021 report by human rights group Liberty found Saudi Arabia had invested more than US$1.4 billion in sports. Much more has since been spent on football, golf, motor racing, cricket and the like.

;

;Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund bought English Premier League football club Newcastle United, and has recruited superstars such as Cristiano Ronaldo and Karim Benzema to the Saudi Pro League.

;

;The sight of a laughing Fifa president Gianni Infantino seated alongside MBS at the Qatar World Cup opening ceremony fuelled suspicions that the kingdom's bid for the 2030 men's World Cup could already be in the bag.

;

;Sport investment is clearly part of the country's economic agenda, but also its political positioning. Such sportswashing is a method used by illiberal regimes to cover up the ugly face of repression. Despite some loosening of controls over women in Saudi Arabia in areas like driving cars, MBS undermined his claim to be a moderniser when 81 people convicted of crimes ranging from murder to “monitoring and targeting officials and expatriates” were beheaded on one day in March 2022.

;

;Critics of the sportswashing concept argue that it is imprecise, and moreover is a routine feature of national and corporate public relations all over the world. It is also used selectively, despite countries like Australia having their own deficient human rights records regarding First Nations peoples and refugees, and trading freely with repressive nations.

;

;But sport attracts greater scrutiny because it is carried on television screens, not container ships. This profile was clear when Infantino was forced, after an angry response by players, to abandon plans to make Visit Saudi a major sponsor of the 2023 Fifa Women's World Cup in Australia and New Zealand.

;

;Saudi tourism may have missed out this time, but Saudi capital will continue visiting many more sports and countries.

;

;David Rowe is Emeritus Professor of Cultural Research, Institute for Culture and Society at Western Sydney University. This article was first published on .

;;

;Florida Governor Ron DeSantis on Saturday condemned Walt Disney World and the US Justice Department – not his chief Republican rival, Donald Trump – as he courted Nevada Republicans deep in the heart of Trump country.

;

;The US “is off the rails,” the Republican governor said. “Insanity is reigning supreme.”

;

;Speaking to Nevada Republicans for the first time as a presidential candidate, DeSantis made no direct mention of the federal indictment of Trump, who is facing dozens of felony counts for mishandling classified documents.

;

;“We're going to end this weaponisation of government once and for all,” said DeSantis, donning an untucked short-sleeve shirt from a podium adorned with bales of hay and bull horns.

;

;The comments come as the Republicans' crowded 2024 presidential class grapples with how to respond to Trump's recent indictment. While some Republicans have raised serious concerns about the charges, DeSantis has largely ignored the situation, touching on it only generally by attacking the Justice Department.

;

;Looking up at Trump in many polls, it is unclear if DeSantis can catch Trump by avoiding one of the dominant issues in the race.

;

;The debate was playing out as DeSantis courted more than 2,000 conservatives, many Trump loyalists among them, who gathered for an annual Basque Fry under a blazing sun at a western Nevada ranch.

;

;DeSantis' team believes he is especially well-positioned to compete with Trump in Nevada, one of the first four states to host a presidential primary contest early next year.

;

;Beyond issues such as his “war on woke,” DeSantis also hopes to benefit from a close personal connection with a top Republican leader. Adam Laxalt, a former state attorney general and host of Saturday's gathering, was a roommate of DeSantis during naval officer training and has long remained a friend. Despite serving as Trump's Nevada chairman during the 2020 election, Laxalt already lined up behind the Florida governor by becoming the chairman of DeSantis' national super PAC.

;

;“I believe Governor DeSantis is the only person in America who can win the primary and the general and be a conservative warrior for all of us,” Laxalt said as he introduced DeSantis.

;

;Disney cancels plans for US$1 billion campus, 2,000 jobs in Florida

;

;Despite his optimism, it was unclear on Saturday how many Republican voters in this pivotal western state were convinced to abandon Trump. There was only a smattering of polite applause as the early speakers tried to cast DeSantis as the Republicans' best hope in 2024.

;

;Don Fautt, a Republican voter from nearby Sparks, Nevada, said he would support DeSantis in the coming primary only if Trump were not on the ballot.

;

;“Trump is the only guy who can go in and fix things,” Fautt insisted. “I get tired of his mouth, but I'll tell you what: He's a warrior. He'll fight. That's what we need.”

;

;Once he took the stage, DeSantis played up his willingness to fight any and all political opponents – especially Disney.

;

;He told his Nevada audience that the children's entertainment giant is “supporting the sexualisation of minors.”

;

;The feud between the Florida governor and the Florida entertainment giant started last year after the company, in the face of significant pressure, publicly opposed legislation concerning lessons on sexual orientation and gender identity in early grades that critics called “Don't Say Gay.”

;

;As punishment, DeSantis took over Disney World's governing district through legislation passed by lawmakers and appointed a new board of supervisors.

;

;DeSantis was speaking out at Laxalt's annual Basque Fry, an event modelled after cookouts hosted by the former Nevada attorney general's grandfather, US Senator Paul Laxalt – the son of a Basque immigrant sheepherder.

;

;Joe Biden says rich need to pay 'fair share' of taxes

;

;In recent years, the event has emerged as a key stop on the Republican presidential circuit, drawing rising stars who hoped to boost their White House ambitions and endear themselves to voters through sampling the local fare. Unlike the pork chops and butter sculptures of the Iowa State Fair, the cuisine at the Basque Fry includes beans, chorizo and – for those daring enough – the event's signature fried lamb testicles.

;

;DeSantis spent much of the afternoon in a large barn with VIPs and event sponsors before taking the stage. His wife, Casey, chatted with attendees outside the barn after her children played on the inflatable bull.

;

;Carlene Rader, a retiree from Carson City, said she is leaning towards DeSantis over Trump. She said she is particularly upset about the allegations against Trump outlined by federal prosecutors last week. The indictment charged the former president with 37 felony counts – many under the Espionage Act – that accuse him of illegally storing classified documents at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida, and trying to hide them from investigators who demanded them back.

;

;“He's done a lot of things that he shouldn't have done,” Rader said of Trump. “Trump's had his time. I like DeSantis a little better.”
